active_learning.discussion_prompt: In groups, debate whether defining an analytic problem using MITRE ATT&CK tactics (adversary goals/'why') versus techniques (specific methods/'how') leads to more effective threat hunting and attribution. Provide real-world examples from known campaigns like SolarWinds or APT28, and reference connections to activity clustering.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Threat Intelligence and Hunting. Topic: Analytic Problem Definition (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Threat Intelligence And Hunting > Threat Actor Profiling > 007_Attribution Methodologies > Activity Grouping and Clustering > Analytic Problem Definition). Incorporate these elements: - Learning Objectives: [insert full list above] - Active Learning: [insert summaries of discussion, peer teaching, problem-solving] - Scaffolding: Build flashcards progressively across 4 layers [insert layer descriptions]. - Prior knowledge: Assume basics in CTI, threat hunting; anchor to MITRE ATT&CK, full Cyber Kill Chain. - Research Context: Analytic Problem = 'what/why/how' of threat gaps; Hypothesis guides hunting; MITRE ATT&CK for TTPs (tactics='why', techniques='how'); links to attribution/clustering. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards per the schema: [insert full flashcard_schema above] Ensure coverage: 30% Layer 1-2 (recall), 40% Layer 3 (apply), 30% Layer 4 (analyze/evaluate/create). Use real-world examples (SolarWinds, APT IOCs). Make engaging, precise, and pedagogically sound for university-level learners.
